comment: Did not know anything about this when purchased.  Nose had a earthy oaky aro a with the smell of ethanol.  The palate was not real hot but did have a smoke and vanilla flavor.  The finish is sustained with some heat and burn.
another delicious OF 100'. a little pricy, but quite delicious. a little citrus and mocha. this is one of my favorite new bourbons...

I've been searching years for old Forrester birthday bourbon.  I've never been able to find it. This is one of two special release old Forrester during 2015.
    
    I'm told by those in the know both these releases are better than the 2015 birthday bourbon. I tried it I like it it's rather inexpensive. And it certainly is a step up from their regular 90 or 100  proof versions

The best nose of my whiskey collection. After multiple tasting with friends, we had a resounding agreement that it smells just like bananna nut bread. Very viscous oily mouthfeel lets you know this bourbon means business. This is a love letter to your grandpas whiskey. The taste is that of a true old school bourbon. Leather, spice, oak, brown sugar, with a twinge of medicinal quality. Not in a negative way. It gives it an old tasting profile. I love this whiskey and everyone I've introduced it to loves it equally as much as I. Classic Brown-Forman whiskey.
Bananas, brown sugar, and cherries throughout.  Bought a bottle and did not regret it.
First sample at Ray's bourbon tasting in winter 2016. One of my favorites. Brought home a bottle. Sadly just had the last drop tonight--1/12/17.

Next up on the Whiskey Row expedition: 1897 Bottled in Bond. Where the 1870 is fruity and light, the 1897 is dark and weighty. There's less of an overt corn note and more aged leather, dark brown sugar, and dulce de leche alongside clove, cinnamon, and oak. Smooth, sweet, and rich with just the right amount of funk to stay really interesting. Cheers to the Bottled In Bond Act!

This has all the flavors of a top notch bourbon,  at an intensity that will put a little hair on your chest.  One of my favorites to date, right at the $50 mark,  and one of the first $50+ bourbon s that convinced me it's worth the premium

Nose is disappointingly average.  It has typical aroma of caramel, vanilla and charred oak; not terribly distinct.  Darker color and moderate legs provide  hope for this bourbon.  It definitely tastes better than it smells.  Overall this bourbon is fairly sweet with some rye spice, and enough oak to moderate the blend of flavors.  The sweet flavors find elements of sulfured molasses, sorghum and singed caramel. Spices are present, but challenging to distinguish individual spice notes.  Black pepper, paprika, and a touch of chipotle powder are present but severely subdued by the sweetness of the bourbon and the bitterness of the oak.   Finish starts sweet, stays long and transitions to a wonderful oak bitterness.  Adding a touch of water did not substantially bring out hidden flavors.   This a hearty bourbon that is best to drink neat.
Really complex and very smooth. A little spicy but not like a rye

Finally getting around to another review.  I've had this bottle for a couple of weeks now, but just getting around to giving it a formal tasting.  Right off the bat, this is a mighty fine bourbon!  The 1897 in the name is a nod to the year the bottled in bond act was passed.  As with all BIB whiskeys, this is the requisite 50% ABV and is at least 4 years old, although there is no age statement on the bottle.

In the glass this whiskey is a very nice dark amber color.  Swirling creates a thick oily coating that produces legs slowly.  The nose is wonderful, full of oak and caramel, with little to no burn.  There is some vanilla and spice notes as well, but mostly just that amazing sweet oak.

The palate is more of the same with sweet caramel, vanilla, and toffee flavors as well as some heat.  The burn is noticeable as it should be with a 100 proof dram but not harsh at all.  Very smooth.  There are some cinnamon and peppery spice notes as well, with a fairly thick mouthfeel.  The finish is fairly long, dry, and oaky.

This is not a complex whiskey.  This is bourbon, plain and simple, but done very well.  The oak tones in this whiskey are some of the best I've tasted, just makes you want more.  It's a fantastic sipper, and pretty good on the rocks as well.  I will definitely save this for those times I want something straight, no mixing for this bottle.  At $50 it is a tad pricey, but worth it in my opinion.  4.5/5.  Cheers!

Just had a pour of this edition of Old Forester's Whiskey Row after spotting it on the shelf at a happy hour.  Undoubtedly, the nose is the highlight of this bourbon -- but it may overpromise concerning what follows.  When I held it far away, just enough to get a hint of the scent, the strongest element was lemon peel.  A more intimate distance yielded sumptuous aromas of maple syrup and vanilla cream.  The nose was enough to get me very excited anticipating what was to come.  In comparison to that nose, unfortunately, the palate and finish are much lighter in character, featuring an airy caramel and syrup flavor, verging at times on malty.  The final notes are slightly astringent, and the drink as a whole has surprisingly little spice for a bourbon at 50% ABV.  The finish is nice, warm, leathery, and a tiny bit minty, but lacking a certain wow factor.  Old Forester 1897 is a solid 3.5, fun to drink, but a bit of a letdown -- particularly in its lack of complexity -- after a spectacular, shapeshifting nose.

Second pour in our pre Derby tasting. Had this in Kentucky a while back, but haven't been back since. Nuttier than I remember. Considering the price I wouldn't return to this one, but it's enjoyable nonetheless.

After trying Jim Beam Bonded, BIB Bourbons seemed to be my kinda thing. Tried this on a Friday splurge.

Color: Amber & Maple Syrup
Aroma: Initially nothing, then that typical sweet bourbon smell.
Taste: Slight rye forward(not sure if there actually was any), corn syrup, hit herbal, slow build up to a mild spice finish. Almost no harsh kick.
Good but a low point in the brand
sweet vanilla aroma, vanilla sip, slight burn spice follow

$49.99 @ TW.
Solid bottled in bond Bourbon. Classic profile with vanilla, oak, brown sugar, caramel and a slight hint of clove. Medium length. Pretty smooth stuff. The biggest issue is at this price point I expect more. EH Taylor SB is superior in every way and $10 cheaper. If you want to stick to Old Forrester, spend the extra $10 for the 1920. It's a much better Bourbon
Bit of a burn...nice and sweet. Lots of vanilla buy again!
Top notch BIB choice a little pricey for what you get in the bottle.
Definitely full bodied but the flavor isn’t speaking to me. Hilton downtown Columbus, OH
Apple skins, oak, honey. Great smell.  A bit rough on the front end. Not as good as 1920.
Strong oak and vanilla on the nose with a little heat. Very nice mouthfeel with oak, vanilla, tobacco. Nice long pepper finish not to much bite.
Sweet on the nose. Vanilla and fruity notes follow. It doesn’t finish like you’d expect a 100 proof bourbon to
very hot and a lot of different flavors, not a bad think but not worth the price
Decent nose. A little sweet nose. Butter finish. Medium to high alcohol finish
5-9-18. 3.7   Not my favorite but very drinkable.  Little to much bite on finish.
I'm a fan of the Old Forester line. They blend sweet and spice to perfection
floral nose, sweet rich cereal, spice on the finish.

Furniture polish, leather, and herbs on the nose. Very smooth, hard to believe this is 100 proof. Some wood on the palate, some spice creeps in at the back if the throat, but not much else. Feels creamy and thick. Tastes like muted old man bourbon but not that intense. Needs some time to open up. 1/11/18

Black Sheep Social Club, Cedar Rapids, IA 
$9/1.5 oz

Nose: 3.75 | sweetness and ethanol, enjoyable but not a ton of depth
Palate: 3.75 | follows the nose; lots of sweetness (caramel, butterscotch) 
Finish: 3.75 | medium-length finish; get a bit of oak and barrel influence on the finish
Price: 3.5 | there are a lot of options at around $50

Verdict: Bar
Really enjoyed this, but at $50 you can find better
Definitely hot at the end. Very tasty.

The nose is wonderful on this and carries a sweet slightly fermented honey fragrance. Definitely carries the signature Old Forester spice on the front of the palette. Something about the finish on this whiskey I just can’t in to though. It’s a bit dry and somehow sour/bitter(?). A few drops of water helps with this a lot.

This is a great bourbon.  Of the whiskeys in my cabinet, I often come back to this one ahead of other highly rated bourbons. I’d give it a 4.5 if this were an option, but I give it a 5 because this bourbon should have a higher overall rating than it has on this app.  The expert description for this one is right on the money...the musty flavor in the finish makes this unique and really enjoyable.
It came in 3rd in a side by side.  1897 was milder than 1920 but not as good as the present day  100 proof (1910 unavailable) The finish was way too short.

Aroma - cherry, oak, sweet
Taste - oak, vanilla, cherry, slight spice
Finish - smooth, medium, sweet finish

neat: full mouth feel. sweetness. long finish. vanilla nose.

one ice cube: nose brings toffee notes.
Sweeter - but quite a bit smoother than statesman. Better than prohibition in my opinion
Great! Loved the spiciness and had a tobacco and woodsy undertone
A nice, solid middle of the road bourbon with a slightly complex taste. Notes of caramel and vanilla stand out on the nose, but the taste has a surprising burst of spiced rye.
Smooth up front, harder on back, good flavor
Smooth on front end, back end bite. A light vanilla aroma.

A dark reddish-copper in color.
Corn oil and dark fruits on the nose on first pour. Later nosings produce a cream soda vibe.
The flavor profile has a unique, zesty tang to it. Mildly sweet with a big, musty oak finish. 
The mouthfeel is not oily, but medium-soft with a nice lingering burn at the back sides of the throat. As it sits, especially in colder surroundings, the mouthfeel becomes thick and lightly gelatinous.
A couple drops of water gives the pour a creamier mouthfeel, but doesn’t seem to add anything to the flavor profile.
A solid bourbon. 3.9.
Hot but in a good way. Get some coffee and very spicy. Really enjoy this.
Crème brûlée, oak, vanilla, and leather aromas. Wood, vanilla, and some spice followed by leather and more wood in the sweet finish.
Sweet/Spicy balance. Nutmeg. Vanilla. Earthy/Nutty finish. Slight cinnamon. White pepper

Taste:  1 oz pour in Glen Cairn with 1 cube of ice

Nose (3.75):  Vanilla and almost like lemon pound cake come forward.  A bit of oak.  Not complex, very straightforward.  I got a stronger nose in original neat tasting.  The ice simplifies the nose a bit.

Palate (4.25):  Some honey-- almost like a bit o honey candy, vanilla, and distinct lemon poppyseed pound cake. The ice/water really enhanced this one on the palate and opened up a sweetness.

Finish (4.0):  I get a smooth burn from the ethanol, taste a bit of caramel and oakiness.  Finish is medium and very traditional with some dryness.  With ice this is a very straightforward and traditional bourbon.  It is not adventurous but it is great quality.  If you are looking for complexity it is not this one.

This is a quality crafted bourbon.  It is not a puzzler but an upfront sipper that I think may have been better with a bit of ice than neat.  The ice quelled the medicinal taste that I wasnt an admirer of without hurting the palate and nose.

Neat, Room temperature, no water added in subsequent tastes, from a Glencairn. Barrel / Batch: undeclared. 

The nose is vanilla and oak, and it isn't subtle about it all.  It kind of leaps out of the glass and smacks you.  There's a certain spiciness in there too... pleasant as a background note.

The palate hit me as a lot hotter than the 100 proof should be.  Heavy on the alcohol, very woody.  But the major impression left was hot.  A second sip seemed hotter than the first.  I've got barrel proofs in the 120's that have less of a bite.

The finish was better, but took a little while to get to appreciate.  It is a long finish, driven by the full-body tackle that was the palate experience.  Once the tingle has subsided, I got to enjoy the vanilla and spice in the finish.  Orange too???  And certainly oak is still prevalent all the way through.

Second taste, added water to dilute a bit, still room temperature in Glencairn:

The nose is sweet, hot, oak, vanilla, and something else sweet... honey perhaps?  More complex and pleasing than before.  Worthy of multiple deep inhales.

The pallet was still warm, even with the addition of water, but greatly improved.  More spice than my first taste.  Still lots of oak.  The burn has hints of ginger in it.

The finish is more enjoyable with water added.  It is still quite long and leaves the tongue warm and coated for a while.  Oak, oak, and more oak prevail.  Vanilla is dancing in there too.

Overall the barrel dominates this whiskey.  I wanted to like it more than I do, but it isn't bad... it's just heavy handed.  I suspect this would make an excellent Old Fashioned.
caramel, cinnamon, apple, and banana, with a bit of tartness in the background, warm and somewhat dry finish with a pleasant lingering old wood note

Of the whiskey row selections this may well be my favorite.

Nose (5):  Caramel, apple, and peanutty.  Sweet and aromatic.  Classic bourbon nose.

Palate (4):  Nose continues on to palate.  No major surprises.  Reminds me of a fresh taffy apple with a touch of smoke and brown sugar.

Finish (4.5):  Just the right finish.  Warming, not burning, crisp and a bit chewy.   Medium aftertaste makes you wanting to sip more.

Overall 4.5.
Tried this at whiskey washback. Very good with notes of banana, caramel, pepper, cherry, vanilla, and corn.
Good. Lots of oak flavor. Get a chocolate Carmel bar at first then really turns into that leather taste.

Glass: deep mahogany color
Nose: rich and bold aromas of vanilla, maple & slight citrus
Palate: Maple, brown sugar, leather and cigar tobacco all joining in. 
Finish: moderate, warm & pleasant
I’ll enjoy it, but I won’t write home about it

On the last pour of a bottle procured a couple of months ago in San Francisco duty free, and the absence of notes until now probably reflects my feeling that this bourbon is merely . . . fine.  Enjoyable, certainly, but without anything to set it apart as a higher-priced limited edition. Nose of cake batter, vanilla, red fruits, some faint hay or grassiness, grape drink. An initial searing heat when the bottle was first opened has been tamed a bit--but there's still a fair bit of fire. Heat and musty wood on the taste, followed by vanilla, char, black tea, bitter cherry, and something reminiscent of an herbal, bitter liqueur. Finish is hot but swift, warming the throat (with the heat persisting), but not a lot of lingering flavour.  At $20 and consistent availability, I'd make this a go-to (like some of the other bottled-in-bonds that punch above their weight-class--think Evan Williams, Old Grand Dad); at $50, you're asking a lot.
Dusty and slightly fruity up front. Ends with wood and a long, but not too heavy, burn.

Overall, this is a whiskey that has good flavors (dark fruits and demmera sugar) , but is fundamentally flawed because it suffers from a medicinal flavor—a strong acetone-like alcohol sharpness that is poorly integrated into the rest of the flavor structure.
nice heat, very smooth. love the spice.
Fruity nose, smooth rich flavor. The typical bourbon tasting notes suddenly turn into a lingering spiced finish. Step up from the old forester signature bourbon but not sure it’s worth the price tag.

Grown up version of its 86 proof counterpart. Still get the fruit on the nose. Taste is smooth and rich with more dried fruit. Burn at the finish is more profound. Good drinker. Didn’t taste as good when paired with dark chocolate.
Nose is off the charts! smooth and delicious. Grab one.

Really smooth, start to finish!
A lot of flavor!
This is a top line taster!
Chocolate, vanilla, oak, cake, cocoa, toasted walnut, pecan pie, cinnamon, butterscotch, buttered toast, corn, heat

Nose: candy, maple

Taste: full flavor, stays on palette, strawberry candy

Great, robust whiskey.
It ticks most of my preferred boxes when it comes to how I want a bourbon to taste.  Not perfectly balanced, but it's a solid B-plus.  This might become my new go to.

Interesting sip. Sweet on the nose, but with major oakiness on the palate. Lots of smoke, tobacco, molasses, etc. Agree with the expert here - there's def something old timey about it, which is almost certainly intentional. Not the smoothest sipper in the world, but it's the kind of pour you imagine yourself drinking by the fire in your hunting cabin. Worth a try
Woody flavor. Smell is low ethanol and reminiscent of pencil shavings, haha.

Lots of alcohol at first, but after resting ten minutes the scents of bananas and butterscotch shine through, with a few faint notes of oak. On the palate the butterscotch melts to a vanilla note that hits the tongue first, with some sweet berries following, ending in a hint of spice that rounds out the flavor. A thick, full (but not sticky) mouthfeel sets up the foundation for a lasting finish that takes nearly a minute to unfold fully. Excellent balance, and an especially tasty pour for those who are already Old Forester fans.
Fairly full taste and relatively low ethanol smell. Might even prefer this to Eagle Rare.
Hint of Cognac/cherry, oak and pepper aroma. Drinks astringent, tannins, oak, not complex
Kind of hot at 100 proof good flavor
Really good, little more burn, really opens up with ice

Thick and high quantity legs, high viscosity 
Nose: excellent nose. Nothing overwhelming or obvious, but good combination of sweet and well balanced. 
Palate - complex and rich, medium to long finish, mild to medium spice, slight oaky content and slight fruity content.
Dust, dusty corn. Add a drop of water, and I get some green apple.
I'm spoiled the 1910 blows this away, I don't think it's the 100proof either. The 1910 is so smooth...
Caramel nose. Honey and cinnamon on the taste with a slightly warm finish. Easily drinkable neat.
Kind of typical whiskey. Good but not special.
Rich vanilla with some honey and caramel notes. Medium to long finish with a bit of a bite.
Spiced and full of flavor. Good with just some ice.

Nose: sweet, spicy, cinnamon, and slight ethanol

Palate: rich, full, sweet with hint of apple, spice 

Finish: medium finish, good warmth in mouth with slight Kentucky hug

Need to try the other Old Forester vintage series. Need to have on stock.

Nose is sweet, leathery and fruity. Sweetness follows on the tongue, delicious serviceberry pie, followed by peppery spice and finally fading to mild woody aftertaste. Old Forester has a distinctive taste. Very nice.
Musty and sweet with less burn than 1920. Rich and lovely.

Color: dark amber
Nose: Brown sugar and all spice
Taste: initially rich taffy that becomes peppery and tannic. 
Finish: lingers on the tongue with a tannic and herbal flavor 
Notes: tasted with one ice cube
Decent. Not my favorite but good

I posted short review on this a while back here is full take:  The only Whiskey row series I hadn't had. Had to try it for $41 at Twins liquor sale. As ive stated before I love everything Old Forester. This is no exception. Poured neat, robust caramel and dark cherry coated candy apple up front. Sweet wood notes with strong rye spice, hell even some dill creeps in. Oily mouthfeel leads palate of delicious varnished candy apple and dark caramel with a mocha nutty note supported by the hefty oak and rye spice kick. Its not the explosion of the 1920 but in some ways for many that's a plus. Don't get me wrong this stuff has PLENTY of rich powerful flavor. Finish is wonderful long oak and drying cinnamon with caramel and nuts wrapped in milk chocolate. Savory and luscious with deep flavors this is another smash hit from OF. I still will take the 1920 but this is hella good...........93/100.......For those who don't care for barrel proof this will be AMAZING with heavy handed flavors that are heated to 100pf. This stuff can run with Col Taylor as best BIB bourbon which is sayin something......Update: going through the bottle it keeps getting better. Really exceptional bourbon imo. Worth getting both this and the 1920 for different levels(this will probably appeal to more people as its easier to handle)
Dust on the nose. Dusty corn on the taste, finishing to cinnamon?
Hint of vanilla is what I taste but super smooth and isn’t a kick in the face like most Bourbons.  It’s really amazing.
Damn tasty. Little spicy. Caramel and vanilla on the nose. Highly recommend.
Vanilla with slight apple and with tartness with a strong leathery finish.
I’ve heat,hints of leather,butterscotch and toffee.
Smells wonderful, like corn and molasses. Deep and well balanced. Taste is sweet, fiery, with a nice spice kick at the end. The spice goes well with the proof. Same old Forrester taste. Love it.
On the sweet side, also quite hot
Nice spice. Not very thick on the tongue, but tasty
Spicy, warm, sweet, peppery, and of course vanilla. Huge apple nose.
Another winner from Old Forester. Really good bourbon. Vanilla and caramel to start. Nice heat at the finish. Definitely a repeat.

Why have I ignored Old Forester until now? One answer is the price of the Whiskey Row series. The other is the underwhelming reviews by the expert reviewers on Distiller. It seems they aren't too keen on the Whiskey Row series, while the user reviews are consistently higher. After buying this I have to agree with users, this is good stuff and I look forward to trying more Old Forester bottles. You can definitely tell it is a Brown-Forman product, I get a lot of similar flavors as I have with Woodford Reserve and its Double Oaked line.

For a BiB it is not as pungent as cheaper BiBs. On the nose I get vanilla, oak, and alcohol. But not overpowering, light and delicate. I get more berries on the tongue in addition to that spiced dessert flavor. Not too oak-forward. I also detect banana as I have with Woodford Reserve and Jack Daniel's. That banana flavor is a dead giveaway for Brown-Forman. I do agree with other reviews that the finish is quick and slightly disappointing. I imagined it would linger longer at this proof. The smoke or mustiness pointed out in reviews is non-existent for me. Overall this is a solid, flavorful bourbon that is a little pricey but you won't regret the purchase. I'm really looking forward to trying the higher proof 1920 next.

BACKGROUND: The 1897 Bottled In Bond expression was the second of four releases in the Old Forester Whiskey Row series of bourbons, which highlights various periods in the Brown-Forman company’s history.

The other Whiskey Row releases include the 1870, which symbolically evokes the original batching process of the first Old Forester bourbon, the 1920, which represents the company’s transition to a medicinal whiskey supplier during the 13 years of Prohibition, and the 1910, a heavily-oaked bourbon highlighting a bottling line fire that occurred at the distillery in the early 20th Century.

The 1897 celebrates passaged of the federal Bottled In Bond Act, which was promoted by large distillers seeking to combat rectifiers that sold low-end, sub-par products under the bourbon standard.

In order to be marketed as “bottled in bond,” a bourbon must meet stringent guidelines outlined in the federal law. The guidelines stipulate it must be the product of one distillery during one distilling season, it must be aged in a federally bonded warehouse for at least four years, and it must be bottled at 100 proof.

The Old Forester 1897 is made from a mash bill of 72% corn, 18% rye, and 10% barley.  It is bottled at 100 proof, as stipulated by the BIB Act, and, because it carries no age statement and must meet the BIB federal requirements, we know if is aged at least four years.

NOSE: The nose offers an interesting combination of both light and dark notes.  The red apple, citrus, and banana scents you would find in a fresh fruit salad are married with oak, leather, and musty goodness that the inside of a rustic rick house offers.

PALATE: A surprisingly full-bodied palate possesses the same apple, citrus, and banana that were present in the nose, but black pepper and spice are equally strong and prominent.  The sweet and savory aspects are each the distinct opposite of the other, but they marry together perfectly.

FINISH: The extra-long finish consists of oak and barrel char, but the well-defined flavor of chocolate mint swirls strongly on the back end.  It offers a good bit of mouth heat kick - perhaps from rye spice - but absolutely no chest hug follows.

FINAL ASSESSMENT: As noted earlier, the Old Forester 1897 offers competing and opposite flavors that combine exceptionally well.  If you like the Brown- Forman taste profile - including its trademark banana presence - you will enjoy this 1897 Bottled In Bond.  If Brown-Forman ain’t your bag, I recommend you go in another direction.

I have sampled all of the Old Forester Whiskey Row series offerings with the lone exception of the 1870 and have, to this point, enjoyed each of them immensely.

Dusty grass and vanilla on the nose. It's spicy with cinnamon, clove, and nutmeg on the taste. The finish is warming and bright, with the dusty notes coming back. With a drop of water out comes the brown sugar and some green apple. Very, very good.
Very nice and smooth. Sweet notes to the nose. Carried a clean light flavor over the tongue and a bit of heat afterwards. I expected a bit more with its 100 proof status. Not a disappointment.
Not much on the nose, but lots of tart cherry tasting
Brown sugar, barrel spice, and dusty corn. Nutmeg. The finish is dry. A little water brings green grass to the nose.
Definitely better than the 1870, but I wouldn't buy it again for my money, the statesman, 1910 and 1920 are the best in the series.
Leather, spice, leather, vanilla, and leather when neat. A little water unlocks musty leather notes. 👞🧳
Very smooth and rich.  Smell warm red apples and a bit of cream brûlée.  Very silky mouth feel and medium smoke tones.  Excellent
Starts sweet and ends with a welcoming spice. Great flavor and unique taste at this price point
Banana and Carmel on the nose.  Carmel vanilla. Oaky spicy finish

-On the nose: Immediate sugary banana like the banana runts candies is accompanied by caramel apple, vanilla, and leather after breathing for a few minutes. A combination that’ll make you think “that smells weird but delicious”. 

-Palette and Finish: banana and caramel apple from the nose hit as soon as this touches the tongue, but are quickly gone and followed by black pepper, spices, leather, and light vanilla that stick with the finish which lingers long enough to be satisfying as these notes fade away. 

The proof feels just right in combination with the flavor profiles. It is warming but leaves room to feel the kick from the black pepper. 
This is delicious to drink and fun to taste. This is the bold flavor I was hoping for and already want to grab another bottle because this is delicious.
On the nose I find candy apples and papaya. The taste brings in cherries, apricots. The finish is warm, and then I get a dusty aftertaste at the very end of the somewhat short finish.
Citrusy, nutty, leathery with a spicy finish....I like it!
The nose is mostly ethanol and some brown sugar. It's peppery and a little sweet on the taste. The dusty corn comes out like crazy on the long finish.

Nose of banana, brown sugar, cherry, and leather with some ethanol heat in the background. 

On the palate we find maraschino cherry, a vanilla/caramel that is reminiscent of flan dessert, and cinnamon. Flavors are sharp; has considerable bite and drinks a little hot for 100 proof. Not terribly complex.

Finishes with yet more cherry, a really nice toffee note, oak, and some barrel char. Finish really lingers. Mouthfeel is on the full side of medium. 

Ch-Ch-Ch-Cherry bomb! In all seriousness this bourbon brings a very “old school” kind of bourbon profile which I guess was the idea. There are some really nice notes, but you do have to like a bourbon that hits back a little. There’s only one problem; the price. At $48, there’s just so many I would buy before this one, so it’s hard to see myself buying this again. But I’ll certainly enjoy the rest of the bottle.
Dark fruit and oak jump out of the glass on the nose. Brown sugar and baked apples on the palate. Who needs dessert when you have this in your glass!
Hint of chocolate at the end, sweet caramel and vanilla
A good bottle in bond, great in an old fashion. Definitely has some leathery old musty taste but in a good way

I get a nose of vanilla, salted caramel and cherry along with some light smoky cocoa. 

Taste is like a boozy cherry cordial! Not unpleasant in the least! This is wonderful! Like a Riesen candy too... slightly brown sugar and molasses with some nice oak and slight burn. 

Great quality! Very solid!
Nose is of brown sugar.  Cinnamon gives way to significant cherry notes.  Is a good bourbon neat.  A smooth, lingering finish.

Nose is a blast of dark fruit with a bit of oak.
The dark fruit on the nose comes through on the palate. Its sweetness balanced with a nice amount of spice.
The finish lingers with the spice being the main player but plays nicely with the sweetness.
